name: vx
Reason: The compound vx has several functional groups that will affect its melting point. Starting with the central ethane (as a basic two-carbon chain), which has a relatively low melting point (around -172 degrees Celsius for ethane): The oxyphosphorane group [OP(C)(=O)S] is a highly polar and bulky group which introduces steric hindrance and increases intermolecular interactions, since the presence of phosphorus, oxygen, and sulfur atoms can facilitate additional van der Waals forces and potential hydrogen bonding, likely raising the melting point significantly. The methoxy group (OCH3) attached to the ethane also increases the molecular weight and polarizability, likely contributing an increase to the melting point. On the other side, the amine group (N(C(C)C)C(C)C) is quite large and introduces additional molecular bulk, which could potentially raise the melting point due to van der Waals interactions, yet at the same time, the multiple methyl groups contribute flexibility, which might slightly lower the melting point or not have a significant effect. Overall, the polar and bulky oxyphosphorane group will play a major role in determining the melting point. Without exact quantitative values for each functional groups effect on the melting point, a precise prediction is challenging. Assuming the oxyphosphorane group elevates the melting point by approximately +150 degrees Celsius, the methoxy by +10 degrees Celsius, and the amine along with the methyl groups raises it by about +30 degrees Celsius cumulatively, a rough estimation can be made.
